overall_score_comment: A solid 4 out of 10 — because apparently 'codependency chic' is the new black, and therapy is so last season.
the_roast:
Oh good, another ballad where dying alone is presented as romance's ultimate failure state. 'Til I'm in the grave, 'til I rot away, dead and buried' — girl, this isn't a love song, it's a hostage negotiation with a casket. You've essentially written a prenup for the afterlife, and spoiler alert: even death is trying to file a restraining order.

Let's talk about 'If you go, I'm goin' too' — congratulations, you've turned Romeo and Juliet into a threat. This isn't devotion, this is the emotional equivalent of 'if I can't have you, nobody can,' except you're doing it to yourself. And 'if I'm turning blue, please don't save me'? That's not romantic, that's a liability waiver. I can see the paramedics now: 'Ma'am, we need to perform CPR—' 'No, no, she left very specific instructions in song form.'

The 'birds of a feather' metaphor is doing some HEAVY lifting here, trying to make 'I have zero sense of self without you' sound poetic. Real birds of a feather actually separate sometimes — it's called migration, honey. They don't cling to each other screaming 'WE SHOULD STICK TOGETHER' while plummeting to earth. And that line 'I said I'd never think I wasn't better alone' is so grammatically pretzel'd, I need a linguistics degree and a chiropractor to unpack it. Triple negatives aren't deep, they're just confusing.

'You're so full of shit, tell me it's a bit' — FINALLY, some self-awareness breaks through the fog of codependency! But then immediately after this brief moment of clarity, we're back to 'don't wanna say goodbye' and death pacts. It's like watching someone almost escape a cult, then voluntarily walking back in because the Kool-Aid slaps. And that past life stuff at the end? Oh perfect, because one lifetime of this exhausting attachment style wasn't enough — you had to make it ETERNAL. Soulmate theory is just astrology for people who are bad at breaking up.

cliche_counter.cliche: 'Til the day that I die' (repeated 47 times, or it felt like it)
cliche_counter.quip: Yes, we get it. You're committed. So is everyone in a psych ward.
The 'I knew you in another life' line is what every person says when they're ignoring red flags in THIS life.
'Can't change the weather' — but you CAN check a forecast and bring an umbrella instead of drowning together romantically.
The battle cry of everyone who's about to make 'our therapist' their entire personality.
Death is literally the one boundary that should be respected, but sure, make it weird.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: 'Til I rot away, dead and buried / 'Til I'm in the casket you carry
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory attendance at a healthy relationships seminar, followed by reading literally any other genre of poetry.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: And if I'm turnin' blue, please don't save me / Nothin' left to lose without my baby
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Weaponizing asphyxiation as a romantic gesture
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Writing 'DO resuscitate' on a medical bracelet while listening to Gloria Gaynor's 'I Will Survive' on repeat.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I said I'd never think I wasn't better alone
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Grammatical gymnastics that would make Yoda say 'Confusing, this is'
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Diagramming this sentence until it makes sense or the heat death of the universe, whichever comes first.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: But if it's forever, it's even better
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Celebrating permanence without an exit strategy like it's a timeshare presentation
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Watching every divorce documentary on Netflix while taking notes on 'signs we ignored.'

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I knew you in another life / You had that same look in your eyes
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Using reincarnation as an excuse to avoid actual communication
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Explaining to your ancestors why you're blaming them for your current relationship choices.

hidden_meanings: This song is clearly a metaphor for the death of individual identity in modern relationships, where we've romanticized losing ourselves so thoroughly that we've made 'I can't exist without you' the gold standard instead of the warning sign it actually is. The birds of a feather aren't sticking together — they're glued together in a craft project gone horribly wrong, slowly suffocating under Mod Podge and poor boundaries.
final_verdict: This is what happens when 'ride or die' stops being a fun phrase and becomes a suicide pact with a melody. Somebody get this song a therapist, a self-help book, and maybe a single goldfish to practice having something that can survive without constant validation.
title: Birds of a Feather
